title: Evaluation of Stoichiometric Accuracy with Deep-Ultraviolet Laser-Assisted Atom Probe Tomography of Hydroxyapatite
content: Hydroxyapatite (HA, Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2) is highly relevant to human health: it is the mineral component of bones and teeth. These tissues are often employed by organisms to sustain large and/or repeated loads in a challenging chemical environment for prolonged periods of time. Pure, monolithic HA is a rather brittle material, but through a combination of complex and hierarchical design elements from the micro- to the nanoscale, it can endure decades of use. Recent studies of human dental enamel have indicated that there exist chemical gradients within the HA nanocrystals (cross section âˆ¼50 x 100 nm), inducing a residual stress on the surface of the nanocrystal to resist fracture while simultaneously improving the resistance to dissolution [1]. Thus, building a strong and accurate understanding of the nanoscale composition is fundamental to further therapeutic efforts to rebuild or integrate with HA-based biominerals.
